name: Aloe
description: Used internally, aloe may regulate blood sugar levels and control diabetes, treat mouth and stomach ulcers, lower cholesterol, and iprovide immune system support, treat inflammatory bowel disease, and act as a laxative. Externally, it is used for skin conditions, burns, and wounds.

intakePractices.dosage: Generally, as a laxative, aloe is used in the range of 50-200 mg/day or about 1-3 oz orally. For topical use, apply as needed.
intakePractices.timing: Can be taken any time of day.
intakePractices.specialInstructions: Consuming aloe vera before meals can help improve digestion and reduce bloating and indigestion. Drinking aloe vera juice after meals can help soothe the digestive tract and reduce inflammation. It can also help regulate blood sugar levels and prevent spikes in insulin after eating.

benefits: Heals wounds, burns, and skin conditions
sideEffects: Rare at recommended doses
No significant side effects of aloe vera gel have been noted, except the occasional allergy.

studies.title: Aloe Vera
studies.journal: The Health Professional's Guide to Dietary Supplements

name: Cayenne
description: Capsaicin or chili peppers of many varieties have both internal and topical uses, including gastrointestinal health, headache, pain (both rheumatoid arthritis and osteoarthritis), and psoriasis and dermatitis.

intakePractices.dosage: The usual dosage for internal use of capsicum is in the range of 30-120 mg, with 60 mg most common. Patients should be advised not to bite or chew on the capsules. For topical applications for pain or skin irritation, the content of creams in clinical studies has been 0.025-0.075% capsaicin, with application 4-5 times daily.
intakePractices.timing: Can be taken any time of day.
intakePractices.specialInstructions: Capsaicin is best absorbed when taken with food. It is important to avoid contact with the eyes and mucous membranes when applying topical capsaicin.

sideEffects: For the topical use might cause burning sensation
Capsaicin and the capsaicinoids are strong irritants to the mucous membranes and can produce dermatitis.

studies.title: Cayenne
studies.journal: The Health Professional's Guide to Dietary Supplements

name: Fiber
description: Dietary fiber is a carbohydrate that is not digested in the small intestine. It is found in fruits, vegetables, whole grains, and legumes. It is important for digestive health and can help prevent constipation, lower cholesterol levels, and control blood sugar levels. Fiber can be classified into two main types: soluble and insoluble.

intakePractices.dosage: Total daily fiber consumption should be within the range of 20-40 g. Popular fiber supplements (taken with 8 oz of water) are psyllium (7 g up to 3 times daily), methylcellulose (10 g up to 3 times daily), and polycarbophil (1 g up to 4 times daily).
intakePractices.timing: Can be taken any time of day, preferably with meals.
intakePractices.specialInstructions: To prevent dehydration, adequate fluid must be consumed.

benefits: Soluble fiber reduces the risk of heart disease by lowering cholesterol levels.
Diets high in insoluble fiber reduce the risk of colon cancer.
sideEffects: The intake of dietary fiber or fiber supplements within the recommended doses is considered safe.
Excessive fiber intake may cause bloating, gas, and diarrhea.
Some sources of the fiber are common allergens

studies.title: Fiber
studies.journal: The Health Professional's Guide to Dietary Supplements

name: Ginger
description: Ginger is a flowering plant whose rhizome is widely used as a spice and folk medicine. It is used to treat nausea, vomiting, and digestive issues. It is also used for its anti-inflammatory and antioxidant properties.

intakePractices.dosage: The usual dosage for ginger is in the range of 1-2 g/day.
intakePractices.timing: No specific timing, can be taken any time of day.
intakePractices.specialInstructions: In the case of gallstones should be taken only after consulting a physician.

sideEffects: Generally safe
High doses may cause heartburn or upset stomach

studies.title: Ginger
studies.journal: The Health Professional's Guide to Dietary Supplements

name: Mastic
description: Mastic is a resin obtained from the mastic tree. It is used for digestive issues, oral health, and as an anti-inflammatory agent. It is also used for its antimicrobial properties.

intakePractices.dosage: For treating ulcers and gastrointestinal discomfort, 1 g of mastic is used.
intakePractices.timing: No specific timing, can be taken any time of day.

sideEffects: Considered safe

studies.title: Mastic
studies.journal: The Health Professional's Guide to Dietary Supplements

name: Milk Thistle
description: Milk thistle is a flowering herb used for liver health and detoxification. It is known for its antioxidant and anti-inflammatory properties. It is often used to support liver function and protect against liver damage.

intakePractices.dosage: Usual of milk thistle is 175 mg/day for extract standardized to 80% silymarin flavonoids. Other daily dosage recommendations vary depending on the preparation
intakePractices.timing: No specific timing, can be taken any time of day.
intakePractices.specialInstructions: Recommended to be taken before meal.

sideEffects: Milk thistle may cause allergic reactions, particularly among people who are allergic to related plants (for example, ragweed, chrysanthemum, marigold, and daisy). Little is known about whether itâ€™s safe to use milk thistle during pregnancy or while breastfeeding

studies.title: Milk Thistle
studies.journal: The Health Professional's Guide to Dietary Supplements

name: Prebiotics
description: Prebiotics are non-digestible food ingredients that promote the growth of beneficial bacteria in the gut. They are found in foods like garlic, onions, and bananas. They are used to improve gut health and digestion.

intakePractices.dosage: The usual dosage for prebiotics is around 10 g/day.
intakePractices.timing: No specific timing, can be taken any time of day.
intakePractices.specialInstructions: Recommended to be taken before meal.

sideEffects: Flatulation
Bloating
Diarrhea

studies.title: Prebiotics
studies.journal: The Health Professional's Guide to Dietary Supplements

name: Probiotics
description: Probiotics are live microorganisms that provide health benefits when consumed in adequate amounts. They are found in fermented foods like yogurt and sauerkraut. They are used to improve gut health and digestion.

intakePractices.dosage: The usual dosage for probiotics is around 1-10 billion CFU/day.
intakePractices.timing: No specific timing, can be taken any time of day.
intakePractices.specialInstructions: People with severe gastrointestinal ailments (e.g., Crohn disease, ulcerative colitis) should consult with their personal physician before consuming probiotic supplements.

sideEffects: Considered safe at recommended levels

studies.title: Probiotics
studies.journal: The Health Professional's Guide to Dietary Supplements

name: Slippery Elm
description: Slippery elm is a tree whose inner bark is used for its soothing properties. It is used to treat digestive issues, sore throat, and skin conditions.

intakePractices.dosage: The usual dosage for slippery elm is around 1-2 g/day.
intakePractices.timing: No specific timing, can be taken any time of day.
intakePractices.specialInstructions: People with severe gastrointestinal ailments (e.g., Crohn disease, ulcerative colitis) should consult with their personal physician before consuming probiotic supplements.

sideEffects: Considered to be safe and nontoxic, with no drug interactions.

studies.title: Slipperhy Elm
studies.journal: The Health Professional's Guide to Dietary Supplements

name: Yellow Dock
description: Yellow dock is a member of the buckwheat family that can be found naturalized in many parts of the world. Used in traditional medicines as a digestive aid, for skin conditions, and for liver health.

intakePractices.dosage: The usual dosage is 1 g/day of the dried root or 3-4 mL of the root extract 3 times daily.
intakePractices.timing: No specific timing, can be taken any time of day.
intakePractices.specialInstructions: Might be toxic if not properly prepared, must consult the doctor before taking. Not recommended while pregnant or breast-feeding.

benefits: Supports gut health and liver health
sideEffects: Contains oxalates that may inhibit nutrients absorption.
Might be toxic if taken raw

studies.title: Yellow Dock
studies.journal: The Health Professional's Guide to Dietary Supplements

name: Alpha-Lipoic Acid
description: Generally lipoic acid is involved in cellular energy production. Additionally, as a dietary supplement it acts as a powerful antioxidant, helps to control blood sugar levels and has antiaging benefits. Alpha-lipoic acid can be eaten in foods, such as red meat, carrots, beets, spinach, broccoli, and potatoes. It is also available in supplements.

intakePractices.dosage: For antioxidant benefits, recommended dosage is 50-100 mg/day. For preventing and treating complications of diabetes, recommended dosage is 300-600 mg/day.
intakePractices.timing: No specific timing, can be taken any time of day.

sideEffects: It is usually well-tolerated. The most common side effects are headache, heartburn, nausea, and vomiting.

studies.title: Alpha-Lipoic Acid
studies.journal: The Health Professional's Guide to Dietary Supplements

name: Riboflavin
description: Riboflavin is a water-soluble vitamin that is important for energy production, cellular function, growth, and development. It is found in dairy products, eggs, green leafy vegetables, nuts, and enriched cereals.

intakePractices.dosage: The daily requirement of riboflavin is 1.1-1.3 mg/day for adults.
intakePractices.timing: Can be taken any time of day.
intakePractices.specialInstructions: Riboflavin is best absorbed when taken with a meal.

sideEffects: Generally considered safe at recommended doses
High doses may cause diarrhea and increased urine output

studies.title: Riboflavin
studies.journal: https://ods.od.nih.gov/factsheets/Riboflavin-Consumer/

name: Thiamin
description: Thiamine is a water-soluble vitamin that is important for energy metabolism and the proper functioning of the nervous system. It is found in whole grains, legumes, nuts, and meat.

intakePractices.dosage: The daily requirement of thiamine is 1.1-1.2 mg/day for adults.
intakePractices.timing: Can be taken any time of day.
intakePractices.specialInstructions: Thiamine is best absorbed when taken with a meal.

sideEffects: Generally considered safe at recommended doses
High doses may cause allergic reactions

studies.title: Thiamin
studies.journal: https://ods.od.nih.gov/factsheets/Thiamin-Consumer/

name: Panthothenic Acid
description: Pantothenic acid is a water-soluble vitamin that is important for energy metabolism and the synthesis of hormones and cholesterol. It is found in a wide variety of foods, including meat, eggs, whole grains, and legumes.

intakePractices.dosage: The daily requirement of panthothenic acid is 5mg/day for adults.
intakePractices.timing: Can be taken any time of day.
intakePractices.specialInstructions: Pantothenic acid is best absorbed when taken with a meal.

benefits: Involed in the synthesis of hormones and cholesterol
sideEffects: Generally considered safe at recommended doses
High doses may cause diarrhea and gastrointestinal upset

studies.title: Pantothenic Acid
studies.journal: https://ods.od.nih.gov/factsheets/PantothenicAcid-Consumer/

name: Biotin
description: Biotin is a water-soluble vitamin that is important for energy metabolism and the health of skin, hair, and nails. It is found in eggs, nuts, seeds, and certain vegetables.

intakePractices.dosage: The daily requirement of biotin is 2.5mg/day for adults.
intakePractices.timing: Can be taken any time of day.
intakePractices.specialInstructions: Biotin is best absorbed when taken with a meal.

benefits: Promotes healthy skin, hair, and nails
sideEffects: Generally considered safe at recommended doses

studies.title: Biotin
studies.journal: https://ods.od.nih.gov/factsheets/Biotin-Consumer/

name: Ashwagandha
description: Ashwagandha is a herb that is known for its stress-reducing and energy-boosting properties. It is also used to support cognitive function and immune health.

intakePractices.dosage: The usual dosage for ashwagandha is around 300-500 mg/day.
intakePractices.timing: No specific timing, can be taken any time of day.
intakePractices.specialInstructions: May interract with many medications, including sedatives, thyroid medications, and immunosuppressants. Consult a healthcare professional before use.

sideEffects: Generally considered safe at recommended doses and when used up to 3 months
High doses may cause gastrointestinal upset, nausea, and diarrhea
Not recommended for pregnant patients
Not recommended for patients with liver disease

studies.title: Ashwagandha
studies.journal: The Health Professional's Guide to Dietary Supplements

name: Alfalfa
description: Alfalfa truly is a nutritive food, with high levels of protein (up to 50%), B vitamins, and minerals. These characteristics may play a large part in explaining alfalfa's claims for energy and reduction of fatigue. Additionally, alfalfa contains saponins, which could explain some of its adaptogenic reputation; its antioxidants and alkalizing nature could explain its detoxification claims. The use of alfalfa for hot flashes and cancer may be explained by its high estrogenic activity.

intakePractices.dosage: Although the clinical study on alfalfa for lowering cholesterol used an extremely high dosage (120 g/day), typical dosages for alfalfa tend to range from 250-1,000 mg 2-3 times daily with meals.
intakePractices.timing: With meals

sideEffects: Possible mild blood-thinng effect

name: Arginine
description: Arginine is a substance that is produced in the body. It plays an essential role in the nitric oxide pathwayâ€”a pathway involved in the cascade reactions responsible for vasodilation. Thus, arginine supplements are associated with cardiovascular health, especially in conditions in which the nitric oxide pathway may not be working sufficiently.

intakePractices.dosage: The daily requirement of arginine supplementation has been calculated to be approximately 8 g/day (for a 70-kg person). Supplements in the range of 8-21 g/day have been used clinically.

sideEffects: May be dangerous to patients recovering from heart attacks
May be dangerous for patients infected with simplex virus

name: Vitamin B-6
description: Vitamin B6 is a water-soluble vitamin. It is also known by the names pyridoxine, pyridoxamine, and pyridoxal. Vitamin B6 performs functions as a cofactor for about 70 enzyme systems, most ofwhich have something to do with amino acid and protein metabolism. Because vitamin B6 is also involved in the synthesis of neurotransmitters in the brain and nerve cells, it is frequently recommended as a nutrient to support mental function (mood) and nerve conduction.

intakePractices.dosage: 2-12.5 mg/day

benefits: Control homocysteine levels for heart health
sideEffects: Long-term use of very high dosages (500 to 5,000 mg/day) is associated with neuropathy that is reversible with discontinuation.

name: Vitamin B-12
description: The water-soluble vitamin B12 is also known as cobalamin because it contains cobalt. The B12 form most commonly used in dietary supplements is called cyanocobalamin. Vitamin B12 is only produced by bacteria, so it is only found in food products of animal origin and in some fermented vegetable products such as tempeh and miso (fermented soybeans).

intakePractices.dosage: 50-800 Î¼g/day

benefits: Control homocysteine levels for heart health

name: Folate
description: Folic acid is a B vitamin that plays an important role in the synthesis of DNA and RNA, the production ofred blood cells, and the maintenance of the nervous system.

intakePractices.specialInstructions: Extremely high intakes of folic acid (1-5 mg/day) have been associated with masking the signs and symptoms of pernicious anemia (vitamin B12 deficiency) and should be avoided

benefits: Control homocysteine levels for heart health
Prevent neural tube defects during pregnancy
sideEffects: Very high dosages may induce sleep and mental disturbances

name: Vitamin B-3
description: Niacin is a water-soluble B vitamin and the common name for two very different compounds: nicotinic acid and niacinamide. Like all B vitamins, niacin plays a role in many aspects of energy metabolism and nervous system function.

intakePractices.timing: For niacinamide, take with food to reduce gastrointestinal side effects. For nicotinic acid, take on an empty stomach to reduce flushing and itching of the skin.
intakePractices.specialInstructions: For high dosages, divide into two or three doses throughout the day.

sideEffects: With high doses of niacin used for controlling cholesterol levels (anything above 100 mg/ day), nicotinic acid can cause skin flushing and itching of the skin as well as headaches and hypotension.

name: Coenzyme Q10
description: Coenzyme Q10 (CoQ10) is found in the mitochondria of all cells and is particularly enriched in tissues ofthe heart, liver, kidney, and pancreas. CoQ10 functions as part ofthe cellular system that generates energy from oxygen (in the form of ATP) for bodily processes and can act as an antioxidant to help prevent cellular damage from free radicals created during exercise and during the generation ofenergy.

intakePractices.dosage: 50-100mg/day
intakePractices.timing: With a meal

sideEffects: Possible epigastric distress (heartburn, nausea, stomachache)

name: Essential Fatty Acids
description: The term essential fatty acids refers to two fatty adds, linoleic acid and linolenic acid, that our bodies cannot synthesize. These fatty acids, like the essential vitamins and minerals, must be consumed in the diet. These essential fatty acids are needed for the production of prostaglandins and eicosanoids, which help regulate blood clotting, blood pressure, heart rate, immune response, and a wide variety of other biological processes.

intakePractices.dosage: Product-specific, typically 1-3 g/day
intakePractices.timing: With meals

name: Garlic
description: Modern-day use of garlic as a dietary supplement generally centers around promotion of heart health by reducing serum lipid levels (total cholesterol, LDL, triglycerides), lowering blood pressure, and inhibiting blood clotting.

intakePractices.dosage: 4-10g/day
intakePractices.timing: With meals

sideEffects: Mild gastrointestinal symptoms such as heartburn and nausea may occur with high intakes

name: Hawthorn
description: Hawthorn is an English shrub that has a long history of medicinal use in herbal medicine, including cardiovascular disorders, digestive complaints, dyspnea, and kidney stones. Today, hawthorn is a popular phytomedicine in Europe for use in cardiovascular disorders. With its ability to increase the integrity of the blood vessel walls, hawthorne can improve coronary blood flow and oxygen utilization and possesses positive inotropic activity.

intakePractices.dosage: 160-900mg, 2-3 times daily

name: Red yeast rice
description: In Traditional Chinese Medicine (TCM), red yeast rice is used for healthy blood and to strengthen the heart; modern dietary supplements use red yeast rice to lower cholesterol levels.

intakePractices.dosage: 1-3g/day

sideEffects: May affect liver functions

name: Soy
description: In terms of health and wellness, the two most important dietary supplements derived from soybeans are isolated or concentrated soy proteins and soy extracts containing high amounts of compounds called isoflavones. Isoflavones have been associated with many beneficial health effects, ranging from protection from cancer and osteoporosis to a reduction in hot flashes and other symptoms of menopause. Soy protein, which may or may not contain a high level of isoflavones (depending on how it is processed) has been associated with a reduction in serum cholesterol and triglyceride levels and may protect against the development of coronary heart disease.

intakePractices.dosage: 25-50g/day

name: Astragalus
description: Astragalus is an herb used in Traditional Chinese Medicine (TCM) for its immune-enhancing properties, but is also recommended in TCM for "deficiency of chi" (life force), which might include symptoms such as lack of energy and fatigue.

sideEffects: Gastrointestinal distress and diarrhea are possible at high intakes

name: Cat's claw
description: Although cat's claw (or una de gato) is generally thought of as only coming from the rainforests of Peru, it is also found in the rainforests of surrounding countries such as Brazil and Bolivia. It has a number of traditional medicine uses, along with current uses such as immune system stimulation and modulation.

intakePractices.dosage: 20-60mg/day

sideEffects: Not recommended for pregnant patients

name: Colostrum
description: Colostrum is the clear or cloudy "premilk" that female mammals secrete after giving birth and before producing milk. Colostrum for dietary supplements is usually derived from bovine sources and contains various immunoglobulins (also called antibodies) and antimicrobial factors (i.e., lactoferrin, lactoperoxidase, lysozyme) as well as insulin-like growth factors such as IGF-I and IGF-II.

intakePractices.dosage: 1-60g/day

name: Echinacea
description: Echinacea is native to the United States and a small region ofsouthern Canada. Although there are nine species of echinacea (Echinacea angustifolia, E. dicksoni, E. dubia, E. gloruisa, E. pallida, E. paradoxa, E. purpurea, E. simulate, and E. angustifolia), only three are normally harvested for medicinal purposes (E. angustifolia, E. pallida, and E. purpurea). Echinacea was originally used in North America by Native Americansfortherapeutic uses such as blood purification and treatment ofsnake bites, infections, and malignancy.

intakePractices.dosage: 1-2g 3 times a day in dired or tea form; reduced dosages for exract or freeze-dried form
intakePractices.specialInstructions: Long term use recommended, chronic use discouraged

benefits: For prophylaxis and treatment of cold and flu symptoms
Increase resistance to flus and colds
sideEffects: May cause allergic reaction in patients with asthma, atopy, or allergies to grass pollens

name: Glutamine
description: Glutamine is the most abundant amino acid in the body, comprising approximately half of the free amino acids in the blood and muscle. Glutamine has two main functions in the body: as a precursor in the synthesis of other amino acids and to convert into glucose for energy.

intakePractices.dosage: 1-20g/day

sideEffects: May cause mild gastrointestinal distress at high dosages

name: Goldenseal
description: Many people consider the main active constituent in goldenseal to be berberine, and most ofthe clinical studies have been done on the single compound. Berberine is an alkaloid that also comes from several other plants which has a long history in folk medicine for diarrhea.

intakePractices.dosage: 4-6g/day for powedered root, 250-500mg/day for extract
intakePractices.specialInstructions: Do not use during pregnancy or lactation.

sideEffects: Long-term use at high doses (500 mg berberine) has been associated with cardiac spasms and death.

name: Vitamin A
description: Vitamin A is a fat-soluble vitamin that is part of a family of compounds including retinol, retinal, and  beta-carotene. Vitamin A is involved in myriad metabolic reactions in the body. As a dietary supplement, however, the most prevalent claims are for promoting skin health, eyesight, and general immune function, with occasional claims made for antiaging and anticancer effects.

intakePractices.dosage: 900 Î¼g/day for men; 700 Î¼g/day for nonpregnant, nonlactating women
intakePractices.specialInstructions: Pregnant women on balanced diets should not take supplemental vitamin A

sideEffects: Very high dosages are toxic and can cause nausea, vomiting, headache, dizziness, and blurred vision, and abortion and birth defects for pregnant women

name: Zinc
description: Zinc is an essential trace mineral that functions as part of about 300 enzymes. As such, zinc plays a role in numerous biochemical pathways and physiological processes. More than 90% ofthe body's zinc is stored in the bones (30%) and muscles (60%), but zinc is also found widely distributed in small amounts in virtually all body tissues.

intakePractices.dosage: 13-23mg every 2-4 hours
intakePractices.specialInstructions: Not recommended to take at periods of more than two weeks

sideEffects: High doses of zinc (gram levels) can cause nausea, diarrhea, and vomiting

name: Bilberry
description: Bilberry has been used in several therapeutic applications because ofits wide range of activities. Bilberry has been reported to be vasoprotective, antiedemic, antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, antiulcer, and astringent.

intakePractices.timing: With meals

name: Grape Seed
description: Grape seed extract has been confirmed in both preclinical and clinical studies to be a potent antioxidant, and it has good clinical evidence of its usefulness in preventing and ameliorating cardiovascular and circulatory disorders.

intakePractices.dosage: 30-150mg/day

sideEffects: Possible mild gastrointestinal discomfort, vertigo, nausea, allergic reactions, and headaches

name: Green tea
description: A number of beneficial health effects are attributed to regular consumption of green tea, and dried or powdered extracts of green tea are available as dietary supplements.

intakePractices.dosage: 100-500mg/day for extract
intakePractices.timing: Consume with or after having food

sideEffects: Possible nausea if taken with empty stomach

name: Lutein
description: Lutein and zeaxanthin are carotenoids found in highest concentrations in the macular region of the eyes (the back of the eye where the retina is located), where they are believed to help filter out damaging blue light and prevent free-radical damage to the delicate structures in the back of the eye. Dietary supplements containing lutein and zeaxanthin are commonly recommended to help prevent age-related macular degeneration (ARMD) and the development of glaucoma and cataracts.

intakePractices.dosage: 4-6mg/day
intakePractices.specialInstructions: Split intake into two doses per day for better absorption

name: Lycopene
description: Lycopene is a naturally occurring carotenoid pigment that is classified as a nonprovitamin A carotenoid. Lycopene is an open-chain unsaturated carotenoid that imparts red color to tomatoes, guava, watermelon, and pink grapefruit. Although not as potent as beta carotene, lycopene acts as an antioxidant and affects cell growth and communication.

intakePractices.dosage: 10-40mg/day

name: N-Acetylcysteine
description: N-acetylcysteine (NAC) is a derivative of the sulfur-containing amino acid cysteine. It is produced naturally in the body and is found in many protein-containing foods. NAC is an intermediary, along with glutamic acid and glycine, in the conversion of cysteine into glutathione (GTH), the body's primary cellular antioxidant. Dietary supplements containing NAC are recommended as general antioxidants and specifically to increase cellular glutathione levels, enhance immune system function, and treat bronchitis and other respiratory conditions.

name: Quercetin
description: Quercetin is a phytochemical found naturally in many foods, such as red wine, green tea, onions, apples, and leafy vegetables. Quercetin exhibits strong antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, and possibly some antihistamine and antitumor activities. Quercetin also inhibits the activity of an enzyme that breaks down norepinephine. These activities are theorized to be at least partially responsible for some of the healthy benefits offoods like red wine and green tea.

intakePractices.specialInstructions: Split intake into multiple doses per day

sideEffects: Possible blood-thinng effects

name: Selenium
description: y. In the body, selenium functions as part of an antioxidant enzyme called glutathione peroxidase and is necessary for normal growth and proper utilization of iodine in thyroid function. Selenium also supports the antioxidant effect of vitamin E.

intakePractices.dosage: 50-200Î¼g/day

sideEffects: High dosages may cause selenium toxicity (nausea, vomiting, depression, irritability, nervousness, skin rashes, and loss of hair and fingernails)

name: Spirulina
description: Spirulina is a blue-green algae that grows naturally in lakes and has been part of the diet supplementation of people in South America, Central America, and Africa for centuries. Spirulina has gained popularity as a dietary and food supplement and for its numerous health benefits, including as a "holistic" multivitamin; for promoting health, wellness, and energy; to stimulate the immune system; for improving blood lipid levels, as a chemoprotective; and for promoting weight loss.

intakePractices.dosage: 2-3g/day
intakePractices.specialInstructions: Split intake into multiple doses per day

name: Vitamin C
description: Vitamin C, also known as ascorbic acid, is a water-solublevitamin needed by the body for hundreds of vital metabolic reactions.

benefits: Prevent and treat colds and flu
sideEffects: Very large dosages may cause gastrointestinal side effects such as stomach cramps, nausea, and diarrhea

name: Vitamin E
description: Vitamin E is actually a family of related compounds known as tocopherols and tocotrienols. It is believed to be able to reduce the risk of cardiovascular disease and cancer, and has also been shown to play a role in immune function, DNA repair, and other metabolic processes.

name: Bladderwrack
description: Bladderwrack, a type of seaweed, is primarily used for its high iodine content, which supports thyroid hormone production. It is often included in weight loss, fat-burning, and energy-enhancing formulations, as well as cosmetic products for skin health. Its trace minerals, fiber, and vitamin B12 content contribute to its nutritional benefits, though it is rarely used alone and lacks clinical support for therapeutic claims.

intakePractices.dosage: Dosage is not well-established due to limited clinical studies. Typical recommendations suggest starting with a small dose and increasing gradually, not exceeding 150 Î¼g/day of iodine as per German Commission E guidelines.
intakePractices.timing: With meals
intakePractices.specialInstructions: Monitor for signs of thyroid imbalance due to iodine content. Avoid if sourced from waters with heavy metal contamination.

benefits: Source of iodine for thyroid support
sideEffects: Risk of thyroid imbalance from iodine excess
Potential heavy metal contamination
studies: Reilly W, Reeve V. Body contouring using an oral herbal antioxidant formulation. Redox Report 2000;5(2-3):144-145.
Phaneuf D, et al. Environmental Research 1999;80(2 pt 2):S175-S182.

name: Carnitine
description: Carnitine, an amino acid found in meat and dairy and synthesized in the body, facilitates the transport of long-chain fatty acids into mitochondria for energy production. Marketed for weight loss, endurance, and cardiovascular health, it shows modest benefits for heart function in specific conditions but limited efficacy for weight loss or athletic performance in healthy adults.

intakePractices.dosage: Typical doses range from 2-6 g/day, often in divided doses.
intakePractices.timing: With meals or before exercise
intakePractices.specialInstructions: Ensure use of L-carnitine, as D-carnitine may cause muscle weakness.

benefits: Enhances heart function in congestive heart failure
sideEffects: No significant adverse effects at 2-6 g/day
D-carnitine may displace active form
studies: Villani RG, et al. Int J Sport Nutr Exerc Metab 2000;10(2):199-207.
Pichard C, et al. Am J Clin Nutr 1989;49(2):283-289.

name: Chitosan
description: Chitosan, derived from shellfish shells, is a dietary fiber that binds to dietary fats, potentially blocking their absorption. It is marketed for weight loss and cholesterol reduction but shows mixed results, with benefits most apparent when combined with a low-calorie diet.

intakePractices.dosage: Recommended doses are 2-6 g/day, in divided 1-g doses with meals.
intakePractices.timing: Before meals
intakePractices.specialInstructions: Not recommended for those with shellfish allergies. May cause gas or bloating.

benefits: May reduce body weight with low-calorie diet
sideEffects: Gas, bloating, diarrhea
Potential fat-soluble vitamin malabsorption
studies: Zahorska-Markiewicz B, et al. Pol Merkuriusz Lek 2002;13(74):129-132.
Maezaki Y, et al. Biosci Biotech Biochem 1993;57(9):1439-1444.

name: Citrus Aurantium
description: Citrus Aurantium, containing synephrine, is used as a thermogenic agent for weight loss and athletic performance. It stimulates Î²-3 adrenergic receptors, potentially increasing metabolism, but lacks robust clinical evidence for fat burning and may pose cardiovascular risks in susceptible individuals.

intakePractices.dosage: 200-600 mg of extract (4-20 mg synephrine) daily.
intakePractices.timing: Before meals or exercise
intakePractices.specialInstructions: Contraindicated for those with cardiac issues, hypertension, or using MAO inhibitors.

sideEffects: Possible cardiovascular effects (increased heart rate, blood pressure)
studies: Kalman DS, et al. Curr Ther Res 2000;61(4):199-205.
Penzak SR, et al. J Clin Pharmacol 2001;41(10):1059-1063.

name: Conjugated Linoleic Acid
description: Conjugated Linoleic Acid (CLA), an isomer of linoleic acid found in meat and dairy, is marketed for fat loss and muscle building. It shows modest benefits for fat reduction in overweight adults but not in trained athletes, with mixed evidence for blood lipid control.

intakePractices.dosage: 3-6 g/day, in divided doses.
intakePractices.timing: With meals
intakePractices.specialInstructions: Prefer blended isomer supplements to avoid potential insulin resistance from t10/c12 isomer.

benefits: Modest fat loss in overweight adults
sideEffects: t10/c12 isomer may cause insulin resistance, oxidative stress
studies: Blankson H, et al. J Nutr 2000;130(12):2943-2948.
Noone EJ, et al. Br J Nutr 2002;88(3):243-251.

name: Guarana
description: Guarana, a Brazilian herb high in caffeine, is used for energy, athletic performance, and weight loss. Its effects are largely attributed to caffeine, though polyphenols and saponins may contribute. No clinical studies support its use as a single ingredient, and it poses risks when combined with other stimulants.

intakePractices.dosage: 200-2,000 mg/day of extract (11-200 mg caffeine), in divided doses.
intakePractices.timing: Before meals or exercise
intakePractices.specialInstructions: Not recommended for caffeine-sensitive individuals, pregnant women, or children. Avoid high doses.

sideEffects: Insomnia, restlessness, heart palpitations at high doses
studies: Boozer CN, et al. Int J Obes Relat Metab Disord 2001;25(3):316-324.

name: DHEA
description: DHEA, an adrenal hormone, is a precursor to testosterone and estrogen. It is promoted for anti-aging, muscle building, and sexual function, with benefits in restoring DHEA levels in the elderly and overtrained athletes but limited efficacy in healthy young adults.

intakePractices.timing: Morning or with meals
intakePractices.specialInstructions: Use only in those with low DHEA levels. Monitor for hormonal side effects.

benefits: May improve bone density and well-being
sideEffects: Virilization in women
Gynecomastia in men
Possible liver abnormalities
studies: Labrie F, et al. J Clin Endocrinol Metab 1997;82(8):2403-2409.
Wallace MB, et al. Med Sci Sports Exerc 1999;31(12):1788-1792.

name: Glycerol
description: Glycerol, a component of triglycerides, is used to enhance hydration by increasing blood volume, particularly for endurance athletes in hot environments. It may delay dehydration and improve performance but is less effective in temperate conditions.

intakePractices.dosage: 1 g/kg body weight, diluted in 20-25 mL liquid per g (e.g., 70 g in 1.4-1.75 L for a 70-kg person).
intakePractices.timing: 1-2 hours before exercise
intakePractices.specialInstructions: Consume slowly to avoid gastrointestinal distress. Avoid in pregnancy, hypertension, or kidney disease.

sideEffects: Headaches, nausea, diarrhea at high doses
studies: Inder WJ, et al. Med Sci Sports Exerc 1998;30(8):1263-1269.
Wagner DR. J Am Diet Assoc 1999;99(2):207-212.

name: HMB
description: HMB, a metabolite of leucine, is used to reduce muscle catabolism during intense exercise and slow muscle loss in conditions like cancer or AIDS. It may increase muscle mass and strength when combined with resistance training.

intakePractices.dosage: 3-6 g/day, in two or three divided doses.
intakePractices.timing: With meals or post-exercise
intakePractices.specialInstructions: Best used during high-intensity training periods.

sideEffects: No significant side effects reported at 3-6 g/day
studies: Panton LB, et al. Nutrition 2000;16(9):734-739.
May PE, et al. Am J Surg 2002;183(4):471-479.

name: Medium-Chain Triglycerides
description: Medium-Chain Triglycerides (MCTs), fats with 6-12 carbon chains, are rapidly absorbed and metabolized for energy. Marketed for endurance, weight loss, and muscle preservation, they show modest metabolic rate increases but limited benefits for performance or fat loss.

intakePractices.dosage: 1-2 tablespoons (14-28 g) daily, starting with 1/2 tablespoon.
intakePractices.timing: With food or beverages
intakePractices.specialInstructions: Not recommended for diabetics or those with liver disease. Start with small doses to avoid intestinal cramping.

sideEffects: Intestinal cramping at high doses (70-90 g)
studies: Keller U, et al. Metabolism 2002;51(6):754-760.

name: Proteolytic Enzymes
description: Proteolytic enzymes, sourced from plants, animals, or fungi, digest proteins and are used as digestive aids, anti-inflammatory agents, and for post-exercise recovery. They show strong evidence for reducing inflammation and accelerating healing.

intakePractices.dosage: Varies by enzyme activity units; typically enteric-coated blends taken 2-3 times daily.
intakePractices.timing: Between meals for systemic effects, with meals for digestion
intakePractices.specialInstructions: Avoid in those with gastric ulcers or on blood-thinning medications.

sideEffects: Mild gastrointestinal upset
Potential anticoagulant effects
studies: Buck JE, Phillips N. Br J Clin Pract 1970;24(9):375-377.
Adamek J, et al. Rozhl Chir 1997;76(4):203-204.

name: Ribose
description: Ribose, a five-carbon sugar, is a component of ATP and nucleotides. It is marketed for energy, endurance, and muscle power, with benefits in preventing exercise-induced ischemia in cardiac patients but modest effects in healthy athletes.

intakePractices.dosage: 3-10 g/day, with higher doses (up to 60 g) studied.
intakePractices.timing: Before or after exercise
intakePractices.specialInstructions: High doses may cause gastrointestinal distress or hypoglycemia.

sideEffects: Gastrointestinal distress, diarrhea, hypoglycemia at high doses
studies: Wagner DR, et al. Ann Nutr Metab 1991;35(5):297-302.

name: Tribulus Terrestris
description: Tribulus Terrestris, a traditional Chinese herb, is used for sexual performance, athletic performance, and as a tonic. Its steroidal saponins and protodioscin may enhance sexual function by increasing DHEA, but clinical evidence for athletic benefits is limited.

intakePractices.dosage: 100-500 mg of 60% saponin extract, 3 times daily, or 750-1,350 mg/day of unspecified preparations.
intakePractices.timing: With meals
intakePractices.specialInstructions: Avoid in dehydration due to diuretic effects.

sideEffects: Frequent urination
Possible hepatotoxicity at high doses
studies: Nikolova V, Stanislavov R. Dokladi na Bâ€™lgarskata Akademiya na Naukite 2000;53(12):113-116.
Adaikan PG, et al. Annals Academy of Medicine Singapore 2000;29(1):22-26.

name: Bee Products
description: Bee Products, including bee pollen, propolis, and royal jelly, are used as immune stimulants, cholesterol reducers, and general tonics. Their variable content of vitamins, minerals, and amino acids supports claims for energy and overall health, though specific benefits lack robust clinical evidence.

intakePractices.dosage: Not specified; varies by product formulation.
intakePractices.timing: With meals
intakePractices.specialInstructions: Use cautiously in those with pollen allergies.

sideEffects: Potential allergic reactions in pollen-sensitive individuals

name: Boron
description: Boron is a trace mineral that supports bone health, aids in the metabolism of minerals, and may influence hormone levels and cognitive function.

intakePractices.dosage: Generally, boron is taken in doses of 1 to 3 mg per day.
intakePractices.timing: Can be taken with or without food.
intakePractices.specialInstructions: Avoid excessive intake above 20 mg/day to prevent toxicity.

benefits: Helps in the metabolism of calcium, magnesium, and phosphorus
May influence hormone levels and cognitive function
sideEffects: High doses may cause nausea, vomiting, or skin inflammation

studies.title: Boron
studies.journal: The Health Professional's Guide to Dietary Supplements

name: Vitamin D
description: Vitamin D is essential for calcium absorption, bone health, and immune function. It also plays a role in regulating mood and reducing inflammation.

intakePractices.dosage: Typical dosage is 600 to 800 IU/day; higher doses may be used for deficiencies under medical supervision.
intakePractices.timing: Best taken with meals containing fat to enhance absorption.
intakePractices.specialInstructions: Vitamin D3 (Cholecalciferol) is more effective than D2 (Ergocalciferol) for raising blood levels.

benefits: Enhances calcium absorption and bone health
May help regulate mood and reduce inflammation
sideEffects: High doses may lead to hypercalcemia and kidney problems

studies.title: Vitamin D
studies.journal: The Health Professional's Guide to Dietary Supplements

name: Calcium
description: Calcium is a mineral critical for the development and maintenance of strong bones and teeth, muscle contraction, and nerve function.

intakePractices.dosage: Recommended intake is 1000 to 1200 mg/day, divided into smaller doses for better absorption.
intakePractices.timing: Should be taken with meals to improve absorption.
intakePractices.specialInstructions: Avoid taking calcium with high doses of iron or certain medications as it may interfere with absorption.

benefits: Assists in muscle contraction and nerve transmission
sideEffects: May cause constipation or kidney stones if taken in excess

studies.title: Calcium
studies.journal: The Health Professional's Guide to Dietary Supplements

name: Vitamin K
description: Vitamin K is essential for blood clotting and bone metabolism. It helps regulate calcium in the blood and supports cardiovascular health.

intakePractices.dosage: Typical intake ranges from 90 to 120 mcg/day depending on age and gender.
intakePractices.timing: Best taken with meals containing fat.
intakePractices.specialInstructions: Consult a doctor before using if on blood thinners like warfarin.

benefits: Improves bone health and reduces fracture risk
May support heart health by preventing arterial calcification
sideEffects: May interact with anticoagulant medications

studies.title: Vitamin K
studies.journal: The Health Professional's Guide to Dietary Supplements

name: Magnesium
description: Magnesium is a vital mineral involved in over 300 enzymatic reactions, including muscle and nerve function, blood glucose control, and blood pressure regulation.

intakePractices.dosage: Recommended daily allowance is 310-420 mg depending on age and gender.
intakePractices.timing: Can be taken at any time of day, often at night to promote relaxation.
intakePractices.specialInstructions: High doses may cause diarrhea; magnesium glycinate is a gentler form for digestion.

benefits: Regulates blood pressure and glucose levels
sideEffects: High doses may lead to diarrhea or abdominal cramping

studies.title: Magnesium
studies.journal: The Health Professional's Guide to Dietary Supplements

name: Boswellia
description: Boswellia is an herbal extract from the Boswellia serrata tree, traditionally used to reduce inflammation, particularly in joint disorders like arthritis.

intakePractices.dosage: Typically 300-500 mg taken two to three times daily.
intakePractices.timing: Best taken with meals.
intakePractices.specialInstructions: Standardized extracts with 60-65% boswellic acids are considered most effective.

benefits: May relieve symptoms of osteoarthritis and rheumatoid arthritis
sideEffects: May cause gastrointestinal discomfort or skin rash in some individuals

studies.title: Boswellia
studies.journal: The Health Professional's Guide to Dietary Supplements

name: Cetyl Myristoleate
description: Cetyl Myristoleate is a fatty acid ester used to support joint mobility and reduce inflammation in arthritis.

intakePractices.dosage: Dosages range from 350 mg to 2 g daily in divided doses.
intakePractices.timing: Often taken with food to enhance absorption.
intakePractices.specialInstructions: Should be taken for at least 30 days for optimal results.

sideEffects: Rare, but may include mild digestive upset

studies.title: Cetyl Myristoleate
studies.journal: The Health Professional's Guide to Dietary Supplements

name: Chondroitin Sulfate
description: Chondroitin sulfate is a compound found in cartilage and is commonly used to manage symptoms of osteoarthritis.

intakePractices.dosage: Commonly used dose is 800-1200 mg daily, often divided.
intakePractices.timing: Can be taken with or without food.
intakePractices.specialInstructions: Often combined with glucosamine for synergistic effects.

sideEffects: May cause mild stomach upset, nausea, or headaches

studies.title: Chondroitin Sulfate
studies.journal: The Health Professional's Guide to Dietary Supplements

name: Devil's Claw
description: Devil's Claw is an herbal supplement used to relieve pain and inflammation, particularly in arthritis and lower back pain.

intakePractices.dosage: Typically 600-1200 mg of extract per day, standardized to 1.5–3% harpagoside.
intakePractices.timing: Take with meals to reduce gastrointestinal irritation.
intakePractices.specialInstructions: Use caution in individuals with ulcers or on anticoagulants.

benefits: May reduce symptoms of lower back pain and osteoarthritis
sideEffects: Can cause gastrointestinal upset, especially at high doses

studies.title: Devil's Claw
studies.journal: The Health Professional's Guide to Dietary Supplements

name: Glucosamine
description: Glucosamine is an amino sugar that helps build cartilage and is widely used for joint support and osteoarthritis symptom relief.

intakePractices.dosage: 1500 mg daily, often split into two or three doses.
intakePractices.timing: Can be taken with or without food.
intakePractices.specialInstructions: Best results seen after several weeks of consistent use.

benefits: May reduce joint pain and stiffness in osteoarthritis
sideEffects: May cause nausea, heartburn, or diarrhea

studies.title: Glucosamine
studies.journal: The Health Professional's Guide to Dietary Supplements

name: Green-Lipped Mussel
description: Green-lipped mussel is a marine extract rich in omega-3 fatty acids and glycosaminoglycans, used to reduce inflammation and support joint health.

intakePractices.dosage: 500-1000 mg daily of standardized extract.
intakePractices.timing: Best taken with meals.
intakePractices.specialInstructions: May not be suitable for individuals with shellfish allergies.

benefits: Supports joint function and cartilage health
sideEffects: May cause gastrointestinal discomfort or allergic reaction

studies.title: Green-Lipped Mussel
studies.journal: The Health Professional's Guide to Dietary Supplements

name: Hydrolyzed Collagen Protein
description: Hydrolyzed collagen protein, or gelatin, is a broken-down form of collagen used to support skin, joints, and connective tissues.

intakePractices.dosage: 5-10 grams per day in powder or capsule form.
intakePractices.timing: Can be taken at any time, often added to beverages or food.
intakePractices.specialInstructions: Ensure adequate vitamin C intake to support collagen synthesis.

benefits: May improve elasticity and hydration of the skin
sideEffects: Generally well tolerated; possible digestive upset in large doses

studies.title: Hydrolyzed Collagen Protein
studies.journal: The Health Professional's Guide to Dietary Supplements

name: MSM
description: MSM is a sulfur-containing compound used to reduce inflammation, support joint health, and alleviate pain.

intakePractices.dosage: 1500-3000 mg daily in divided doses.
intakePractices.timing: Can be taken with meals to avoid stomach upset.
intakePractices.specialInstructions: Start with a lower dose and increase gradually to minimize side effects.

benefits: Supports skin, hair, and nail health
sideEffects: May cause bloating, fatigue, or headache

studies.title: MSM
studies.journal: The Health Professional's Guide to Dietary Supplements

name: Sea Cucumber
description: Sea cucumber is a marine animal extract used in traditional medicine for its anti-inflammatory, joint-supporting, and immune-boosting properties.

intakePractices.dosage: 500-1000 mg daily of dried or powdered extract.
intakePractices.timing: Can be taken with or without food.
intakePractices.specialInstructions: Ensure product is from a reputable source to avoid contamination.

benefits: Supports joint and connective tissue health
Traditionally used for wound healing and inflammation
sideEffects: May cause allergic reactions in sensitive individuals

studies.title: Sea Cucumber
studies.journal: The Health Professional's Guide to Dietary Supplements

name: 5-HTP
description: 5-HTP is a naturally occurring amino acid used to support mood, reduce anxiety, and improve sleep by increasing serotonin levels in the brain.

intakePractices.dosage: Typical dose is 100-300 mg per day, often divided into 2-3 doses.
intakePractices.timing: Best taken before meals or in the evening for sleep support.
intakePractices.specialInstructions: Avoid combining with SSRIs or MAOIs due to risk of serotonin syndrome.

benefits: May reduce symptoms of depression and anxiety
sideEffects: Possible nausea, drowsiness, or gastrointestinal discomfort

studies.title: 5-HTP
studies.journal: The Health Professional's Guide to Dietary Supplements

name: Phosphatidylserine
description: Phosphatidylserine is a phospholipid that plays a key role in cell membrane integrity and cognitive function.

intakePractices.dosage: Common dose is 100 mg taken 2-3 times daily.
intakePractices.timing: Can be taken with meals for better absorption.
intakePractices.specialInstructions: May interact with blood thinners and cholinergic drugs.

benefits: May reduce cortisol and improve mood
sideEffects: Rare but may include insomnia or stomach upset

studies.title: Phosphatidylserine
studies.journal: The Health Professional's Guide to Dietary Supplements

name: Choline
description: Choline is an essential nutrient involved in liver function, brain development, and muscle movement.

intakePractices.dosage: Recommended intake is 425-550 mg daily depending on age and gender.
intakePractices.timing: Can be taken at any time of day.
intakePractices.specialInstructions: Excessive intake may cause a fishy body odor or hypotension.

benefits: Supports brain health and neurotransmitter synthesis
Promotes liver function and fat metabolism
sideEffects: Excessive doses may lead to low blood pressure or body odor

studies.title: Choline
studies.journal: The Health Professional's Guide to Dietary Supplements

name: SAMe
description: SAMe is a compound naturally found in the body that supports mood, liver health, and joint comfort.

intakePractices.dosage: Common dose is 400-1600 mg daily in divided doses.
intakePractices.timing: Best taken on an empty stomach.
intakePractices.specialInstructions: Gradual dose increase is advised to avoid gastrointestinal side effects.

benefits: May improve joint health and liver function
sideEffects: Possible nausea, dry mouth, or anxiety at high doses

studies.title: SAMe
studies.journal: The Health Professional's Guide to Dietary Supplements

name: Feverfew
description: Feverfew is a medicinal herb traditionally used to prevent migraines and alleviate inflammation.

intakePractices.dosage: Typically 100-300 mg daily of standardized extract containing 0.2%-0.4% parthenolide.
intakePractices.timing: Taken once daily, with or without food.
intakePractices.specialInstructions: Do not abruptly discontinue after long-term use; may cause rebound headaches.

benefits: May reduce frequency and severity of migraines
sideEffects: Mouth ulcers, gastrointestinal upset, or allergic reactions

studies.title: Feverfew
studies.journal: The Health Professional's Guide to Dietary Supplements

name: St. John's Wort
description: St. John's Wort is an herbal remedy commonly used for mild to moderate depression and mood disorders.

intakePractices.dosage: 300 mg three times daily of standardized extract (0.3% hypericin).
intakePractices.timing: Taken with meals.
intakePractices.specialInstructions: Interacts with many medications including antidepressants, contraceptives, and anticoagulants.

benefits: Improves mood and alleviates symptoms of mild depression
sideEffects: Photosensitivity, dizziness, and gastrointestinal symptoms

studies.title: St. John's Wort
studies.journal: The Health Professional's Guide to Dietary Supplements

name: Ginkgo biloba
description: Ginkgo biloba is an herbal extract known for enhancing memory, concentration, and blood circulation.

intakePractices.dosage: 120-240 mg per day in divided doses.
intakePractices.timing: Taken with meals to reduce risk of gastrointestinal side effects.
intakePractices.specialInstructions: Use caution with anticoagulant medications; may increase bleeding risk.

benefits: Improves circulation, particularly in the brain
sideEffects: Headache, dizziness, or gastrointestinal discomfort

studies.title: Ginkgo biloba
studies.journal: The Health Professional's Guide to Dietary Supplements

name: Valerian
description: Valerian is a root extract traditionally used to promote relaxation, relieve anxiety, and improve sleep quality.

intakePractices.dosage: 400-900 mg taken 30 minutes to 2 hours before bedtime.
intakePractices.timing: Primarily used in the evening or at night.
intakePractices.specialInstructions: Do not combine with alcohol or sedatives; effects may be delayed with first use.

sideEffects: Drowsiness, dizziness, or vivid dreams

studies.title: Valerian
studies.journal: The Health Professional's Guide to Dietary Supplements

name: Kava Kava
description: Kava Kava is a root extract used traditionally in the South Pacific to relieve anxiety, stress, and promote calmness.

intakePractices.dosage: 60-250 mg kavalactones daily, often standardized.
intakePractices.timing: Evening use is common due to its sedative effects.
intakePractices.specialInstructions: Long-term use may cause liver toxicity; avoid alcohol and hepatotoxic drugs.

sideEffects: Liver toxicity, drowsiness, and potential drug interactions

studies.title: Kava Kava
studies.journal: The Health Professional's Guide to Dietary Supplements

name: Melatonin
description: Melatonin is a hormone that regulates sleep-wake cycles, often used to treat insomnia and jet lag.

intakePractices.dosage: 0.5-5 mg taken 30 minutes before bedtime.
intakePractices.timing: Evening or bedtime use.
intakePractices.specialInstructions: Start with a lower dose; light exposure during the day can improve effectiveness.

benefits: May reduce symptoms of jet lag and insomnia
sideEffects: Drowsiness, dizziness, or vivid dreams

studies.title: Melatonin
studies.journal: The Health Professional's Guide to Dietary Supplements

name: Vinpocetine
description: Vinpocetine is a synthetic compound derived from the periwinkle plant, used to support brain function and blood flow.

intakePractices.dosage: 5-20 mg daily, typically in divided doses.
intakePractices.timing: Best taken with food to enhance absorption.
intakePractices.specialInstructions: May lower blood pressure; use caution in hypotensive individuals.

sideEffects: May cause flushing, nausea, or lowered blood pressure

studies.title: Vinpocetine
studies.journal: The Health Professional's Guide to Dietary Supplements

name: Iron
description: Iron is one of the most plentiful trace metals on earth. It is essential for the formation of red blood cells and hemoglobin and is a constituent of myoglobin, which carries oxygen in muscle. A deficiency in iron decreases oxygen delivery to cells and can result in an iron deficiency that can lead to anemia.

intakePractices.dosage: 8mg/day for adult men, 18mg/day for adult women
intakePractices.specialInstructions: Children and adolescents should not take iron supplements unless prescribed by a healthcare provider. Iron supplements should be taken with food to reduce gastrointestinal side effects. Avoid taking iron with calcium, dairy products, or antacids, as these can interfere with absorption.

benefits: Improves cognitive function in iron-deficient children and adolescents

name: Chromium
description: Chromium is an essential trace mineral that, in the form of a low molecular weight chromium binding substance, potentiates insulin, which influences carbohydrate, lipid, and protein metabolism.

intakePractices.dosage: 120Î¼g/day

benefits: Improve activity of insulin and reduce blood sugar
Reduce body fat and increase lean body mass
sideEffects: May experience headaches, sleep disturbances, and mood swings after intake; may acculumate in body after long-term use and cause undersired side effects

name: Iodine
description: Iodine is a mineral found in some foods. The body needs iodine to make thyroid hormones. These hormones control the bodyâ€™s metabolism and many other important functions. The body also needs thyroid hormones for proper bone and brain development during pregnancy and infancy.

intakePractices.dosage: 150mcg/day for adults

name: Senna
description: Senna is the fruit (pod) or leaf of the plant Senna alexandrina. It is approved in the US as a laxative for short-term treatment of constipation. Senna contains many chemicals called sennosides. Sennosides irritate the lining of the bowel, which causes a laxative effect.

intakePractices.dosage: 1-2g/day in dried form
intakePractices.timing: In the morning or at bedtime.
intakePractices.specialInstructions: Should not be taken for more than 10 days consecutively.

sideEffects: Prolonged use can lead to chronic diarrhea, weight loss, electrolyte imbalance, hypokalemia, changes in heart rhythm, and clubbing of the fingers and toes.

name: Turmeric
description: Turmeric, a plant in the ginger family, is native to Southeast Asia. Today, turmeric is promoted as a dietary supplement for a variety of conditions, including arthritis, digestive disorders, respiratory infections, allergies, liver disease, depression, and many others.

intakePractices.dosage: 375-500mg, 3-4 times a day

name: Ashwagandha
description: Ashwagandha is an evergreen shrub that grows in Asia and Africa. It is commonly used for stress. Ashwagandha contains chemicals that might help calm the brain, reduce swelling, lower blood pressure, and alter the immune system.

intakePractices.dosage: <1000mg/day
intakePractices.specialInstructions: Taking it for periods longer than 3 months may cause undesired effects.
